title.narrative: Second Governance and Competitiveness Development Policy Operation

description.narrative: The objective of the Second Governance and Competitiveness Development Policy Operation Project for Sao Tome and Principe is to assist the government to: (i) strengthen economic governance, with a focus on improving the transparency, monitoring and accountability of public and natural resources, improving the management and reporting of statistics, promoting fiscal stability, and strengthening public debt management; and (ii) support broad-based growth by improving the investment climate, with a focus on simplifying business regulations and reducing the cost of international trade, and by promoting economic diversification. The Bank will focus on the following areas: fiscal and debt management and performance; public expenditure and financial management; and the investment climate.

baseline.value: No forward estimates of fiscal aggregates are undertaken (PEFA 2010)

target.value: Forecasts of fiscal indicators reflecting the major categories of budget classification are prepared for at least three years, andare made available to the public

actual.value: With support from the DPO1 and DPO2 medium-term fiscal planning has improved significantly, with fiscal targets now explicitlyincorporated into the budget process. In line with the SAFE Law the government developed, for the first time, a medium-term fiscalframework (MTFF), which was integrated into the 2013 Budget Proposal. The updated MTFF for the period 2014-2016 has also beenpublished as part of the pre-budget proposal submitted in October 2013, reaching the final objective of the DPO program.

title.narrative: Number of STP visas processed through the electronic visa system

comment.narrative: With support from this DPO series, the authorities are developing an on-line visa system to facilitate the issuance of touristvisas. The system still suffers from minor technical issues but is expected to be fully operational in 2014. In the meantime thesystem is enabling the remote processing of visa requests. Data from the authorities show that the system received an average of400 visas per month between July 2012 and January 2013, and 600 visas per month between January and April 2013, for a total of 6000visa sincethe launch in July 2012. Of these, data from the authorities show that the system provided authorization for 1892 visas.

title.narrative: Reduction in public sector arrears to EMAE

actual.value: With support from DPO1 and DPO2, the authorities verified and approved the total stock of arrears of local and regionalgovernmentsto EMAE and included in its Budget Proposal dedicated budget lines for utility payments (for electricity and water andfor telecommunications) for all line ministries and local and regional governments. These efforts led to a continuos decrease inarrears owned bythe Treasury to EMAE. The total stock of public-sector arrears owed to EMAE at the end of December 2013 was reducedby the Government to about 8 billion dobras. The government is further committed to clear all remaining arrears towards EMAE in2014 and is currently discussing plans to improve the operational efficiency and financial sustainability of EMAE, which is nowthreatened by its ownaccumulated arrears to ENCO.

baseline.value: Financial statements not produced. Court of Accounts cannot carry out an audit, which reduces public sector accountability (2011)

target.value: Public financial statements: (i) are submitted to the Court of Accounts for auditing within 15 months of the end of the fiscalyear; (ii) are made available to the public within one month of their completion; and (iii) are presented in a consistent formatover time with an explanation of its accounting standards

actual.value: With the support of the forthcoming DPO3, the government published the 2010 General State Accounts in June 2013, the first time intwo decades. The 2011 General State Accounts were presented to the Court of Audit at the end of 2013. The government is alsoworkingon the 2012 Government Accounts, expected to be published in 2014. Despite this impressive achievement the General StateAccounts were not submitted within 15 months. Despite the fact that the Court of Accounts has not made any declaration, the publicaccounts donot seem to provide comprehensive information about the asset of the State yet. Specifically, the CGE 2011 contains onlyinformation on vehicles. The Government is currently seeking technical assistance to update the legislator framework, which willallow a proper inventory of this part of the patrimony and to modernize the registry and cadaster of the State.

title.narrative: Availability to the public of fishing agreements, registry and evolution of both industrial and artisanal fishing capacity

baseline.value: Fishing agreements and related information is not public

target.value: All current fishing agreements and a registry of fishing licenses are made accessible to the public on a regular and timely basis

actual.value: With the support of the DPO2 the authorities published all existing fishing agreements, as well as a complete inventory of fishinglicenses for industrial vessels. With the support of the forthcoming DPO3 the government enacted a decree mandating the routine andsystematic public disclosure of all new fishing agreements and of the issuance of all new fishing licenses no later than one monthafter the agreements are signed or the licenses are issued.

baseline.value: Legislation does not meet the minimum requirements of the DeMPA methodology.

target.value: Debt legislation provides clear authorization to borrow, to issue new debt, to undertake debt-related transactions, and to issueloan guarantees. It (i) includes clear debt management objectives; (ii) mandates annual reporting to the National Assembly; and(iii) requires external audits

actual.value: Since 2012 the government has taken steps to improve debt management, but reforms have progressed at a slower pace thananticipated. In 2012 the government completed a medium-term reform plan to improve debt management. With the support of the DPO1the government began to implement this reform plan, first by submitting to the National Assembly an annual report oncentral-government debt, andthen by publishing this report. title.narrative: Application of EITI principles and criteria

baseline.value: STP was delisted from the EITI in 2010 and is not an EITI Candidate Country

target.value: An STP-EITI Committee is operational and receives dedicated budget resources; a Reconciliation Report, in line with EITIspecifications and covering STP's petroleum-related payments through 2012, as well as a Validation Report of the EITI process, areaccessible to the public

actual.value: With the support of the DPO2, STP became an EITI candidate, established the EITI National Committee and introduced a dedicatedbudget line in the 2013 Budget to finance EITI activities. In June 2013 the International EITI Secretariat adopted a new set ofstandards, which has affected the timing of the presentation of the EITI report. The previous standards focused on reconcilingprivate-sector payments at the company level with public revenue. To further improve the transparency and quality of datareporting, the International EITI Secretariat adopted a new set of standards June 2013, which establish additional disclosurerequirements and specify further contextual information to be included in the Reconciliation Report. As a result the reconciliationreport is now expected to be released by October 2014.
